text:
Safran (ENXTPA:SAF) is making headlines as it partners with Bell to complete over 700 hours of flight tests using Sustainable Aviation Fuel in the Bell 505. The company’s helicopter engines will soon be able to operate on 100% SAF, which signals a clear move toward greater sustainability in the industry.

As Safran pushes deeper into sustainable aviation tech, investors have taken notice, with its share price climbing more than 34% year-to-date, backed by a robust 34% total shareholder return over the past year. The long-term momentum is just as impressive, with a three-year total return topping 150%, suggesting that optimism is building around Safran’s ability to navigate new industry challenges and opportunities.

If you’re interested in other companies shaping the future of aerospace and defense, there’s never been a better time to explore

With the stock up strongly this year and trading just below analyst targets, is Safran undervalued given its innovation in sustainable aviation, or is the market already factoring in its future growth potential?

Most Popular Narrative: 12% Undervalued

Safran’s widely followed narrative points to a fair value above its last close price, reflecting strategic optimism about future growth and margin resilience. With analysts factoring in upcoming catalysts and robust sector tailwinds, the current share price appears to lag their broader outlook.

The recent acquisition of Collins' actuation and flight control assets, along with other targeted acquisitions and strategic partnerships, will broaden Safran's mission-critical offering, drive cost synergies through 2028, and further diversify revenue streams. This is expected to result in higher EBIT margins and more stable earnings.

Want to know which bold strategy shifts are behind this valuation? The forecast depends on major boosts to free cash flow, new tech bets, and a game-changing margin play. Discover how all the pieces fit together in the full breakdown and see which financial projections hold the key.

Result: Fair Value of €328.67 (UNDERVALUED)

However, ongoing supply chain pressures and significant integration challenges from recent acquisitions could still threaten Safran’s projected earnings momentum and valuation upside.

Another View: Multiple Approach Challenges the Outlook

Taking a look through the lens of the price-to-earnings ratio, Safran appears well-priced compared to both its direct peers and the industry average. However, it trades above its fair ratio (27.9x vs 27x). This small premium suggests there could be less upside left than the growth narrative implies. Is the current optimism already priced in, or is there still room for a surprise?

title: Lufthansa Cargo and CEVA Logistics Seal Long-Term SAF Agreement to Advance ...
description:
Lufthansa Cargo and CEVA Logistics have turned their summer Memorandum of Understanding on sustainable aviation fuel into a binding agreement.
The deal was signed on November 21 during CEVA Logistics’ Airfreight Annual Strategic Partners Council in Paris.
For Lufthansa Cargo, the agreement reinforces its close cooperation with CEVA, especially on future-focused topics such as sustainability.
“CEVA Logistics’ decision to scale up its use of SAF reflects a clear commitment to advancing the decarbonisation of air freight.
The agreement strengthens their joint effort to deliver verifiable CO₂ reduction and deepen cooperation on sustainable logistics.
text:
Lufthansa Cargo and CEVA Logistics have turned their summer Memorandum of Understanding on sustainable aviation fuel into a binding agreement. The deal was signed on November 21 during CEVA Logistics’ Airfreight Annual Strategic Partners Council in Paris. CEVA has committed to using SAF credits in 2025, representing an emissions reduction of 8,000 tonnes of CO₂.

The MoU has now been formalised into a long-term framework agreement that runs through 2028. Both companies describe it as the result of a long-standing relationship built on transparency, steady collaboration and shared learning. “This agreement marks an important step in our sustainable partnership with Lufthansa Cargo. It allows us to cut emissions in a measurable way and strengthen the sustainability of our supply chains, supported by a partner committed to transparency, strong standards and credible certification,” said Loïc Gay, Global Air & Ocean Products VP at CEVA Logistics.

For Lufthansa Cargo, the agreement reinforces its close cooperation with CEVA, especially on future-focused topics such as sustainability. “CEVA Logistics’ decision to scale up its use of SAF reflects a clear commitment to advancing the decarbonisation of air freight. Protecting the climate depends on strong partnerships and determined action, and this agreement gives us a solid base to move forward together,” said Anand Kulkarni, Head of Global Markets.

The framework also sets out how both sides will continue to collaborate on SAF and plan additional measures over time. The fuel used is produced only from waste and residual materials, contains no palm oil and meets leading international sustainability standards. Emission reductions will be validated for CEVA through audited mitigation certificates, supported by Lufthansa Cargo’s certified Proof of Sustainability process. The agreement strengthens their joint effort to deliver verifiable CO₂ reduction and deepen cooperation on sustainable logistics.

This SAF commitment builds on a wider sustainability partnership between the two companies, including shared expertise, circular economy initiatives and joint innovation and research projects.

title: Star Air eyes first direct Embraer order as it targets 50 aircraft by 2030
description:
The carrier began operations in January 2019 and has grown during the pandemic, leveraging India’s UDAN government subsidy program.
Star Air aims to increase its fleet to 50 aircraft by 2030, supporting a network that now includes 31 cities.
Embraer has not yet secured an order from Indian airlines, a situation that Star Air could also take advantage of.
Star Air recently completed the first tranche of a funding round.
Star Air plans to operate 20 aircraft by April 2028, which would enable the launch of international flights under these new provisions.
text:
Star Air, currently India’s largest regional airline, is considering a substantial Embraer aircraft order for next year as it looks to expand its operations beyond its present fleet of 11 aircraft, all from the Brazilian manufacturer.

The carrier began operations in January 2019 and has grown during the pandemic, leveraging India’s UDAN government subsidy program. Star Air aims to increase its fleet to 50 aircraft by 2030, supporting a network that now includes 31 cities.

“In our fleet current, four aircraft are owned and the rest are leased,” said Managing Director Shrenik Ghodawat, from the Sanjay Ghodawat Group, parent company of the airline, to The Times of India.

Follow us: WhatsApp | BlueSky | Google News | Instagram | LinkedIn | Facebook

According to Ghodawat, the airline operates 56 daily flights, with 65% of these falling under the UDAN scheme. “Today we have 56 daily flights, with 65% being UDAN, in our network of 31 cities,” he said.

The Bengaluru-based carrier has four 50-seat ERJ-145s and seven E175s. These jets began arriving on lease in 2023 in a two-class configuration (12+64), but in 2025 four aircraft with 88 seats in a single class were received.

However, Ghodawat did not specify which aircraft are being evaluated at Embraer. Besides the already operated E175s, other alternatives include the E190-E2 for approximately 110 passengers, and the E195-E2, with up to 146 seats.

The E2 models, however, are more expensive, although they offer a lower operating cost per seat. Embraer has not yet secured an order from Indian airlines, a situation that Star Air could also take advantage of.

Star Air recently completed the first tranche of a funding round. The company has outlined plans to develop proprietary facilities for maintenance, repair, and crew training to support its growth trajectory.

The Indian government has indicated intentions to extend the UDAN scheme to nearby international routes. Star Air plans to operate 20 aircraft by April 2028, which would enable the launch of international flights under these new provisions.

title: Thirty Eighth Report - Delegated Powers and Regulatory Reform Committee - Parliament UK
description:
4.The Department for Transport has provided a Delegated Powers Memorandum (“the Memorandum”) explaining and justifying the Bill’s delegated powers.
The Bill includes twelve delegated powers two of which, in clauses 1(8) and 11(4)(a), are Henry VIII powers.
5.This note draws the House’s attention to one delegated power.
Clause 11(4)(b)–determination of turnover 6.The Bill confers delegated powers to raise and dispose of levy funding.
The approach taken by the Government to clause 11(4)(a) accords with this principle.
text:
Thirty Eighth Report Contents

Thirty Eighth Report

Sustainable Aviation Fuel Bill

1. The Sustainable Aviation Fuel Bill was brought to the House of Lords on 20 October 2025. Second reading was on 20 November and Committee Stage is scheduled to begin on 10 December.

2.Sustainable Aviation Fuel (“SAF”) is a lower carbon aviation fuel and the Government considers its use to be “one of the most effective ways to reduce aviation emissions right now”. However, in the Government’s view a number of risks discourage investment and hinder the development of a market in SAF production. One of these perceived risks is revenue uncertainty risk.

3.The Bill is intended to establish a revenue certainty mechanism to support SAF production and long-term investment in the United Kingdom. The Bill will enable the Secretary of State to designate a contractual counterparty, wholly owned by Government, and direct it to enter into contracts with producers that guarantee a price for their SAF over a set period; under the contracts the counterparty will pay producers the difference between the market price and a guaranteed “strike price” (if the strike price is higher) or receive the difference from the producer (if the strike price if lower). A levy on suppliers of aviation fuel will fund the mechanism and its administration.

4.The Department for Transport has provided a Delegated Powers Memorandum (“the Memorandum”) explaining and justifying the Bill’s delegated powers. The Bill includes twelve delegated powers two of which, in clauses 1(8) and 11(4)(a), are Henry VIII powers. Both of these appear to be justified and comply with our frequently cited presumption that such powers should be subject to affirmative procedure unless there is compelling justification to the contrary. However we are disappointed that the Memorandum does not acknowledge that the Bill includes Henry VIII powers. Our Guidance for Departments requires that such powers are clearly identified.

5.This note draws the House’s attention to one delegated power.

Clause 11(4)(b)–determination of turnover

6.The Bill confers delegated powers to raise and dispose of levy funding. Exercise of these powers will necessarily involve imposing statutory duties on suppliers of aviation fuel. Clause 11(1) confers a power on the Secretary of State to enforce these duties by imposing a financial penalty on suppliers who are in breach. The maximum amount of the penalty appears on the face of the Bill in clause 11(3) as the lesser of:

£100,000, and

an amount equal to 10% of turnover of the person on whom it is imposed.

7.Clause 11(4) is a delegated power that allows regulations to be made:

(a)amending the figure of £100, 000 in the light of inflation, and

(b)setting out how turnover is to be determined.

8.Regulations exercising the power in (a) are subject to affirmative provision and those exercising the power in (b) are subject to negative procedure.

9.We have consistently taken the view that the maximum amount of any financial penalty should be set out on the face of a Bill with, where necessary, a delegated power subject to affirmative procedure to vary that amount. The approach taken by the Government to clause 11(4)(a) accords with this principle.

10.It also seems reasonable in our view for the Government to seek the delegated power in clause 11(4)(b) to set out how turnover is to be determined since doing so is likely to involve technical detail and will involve judgments about fair treatment of those subject to the levy. However, clause 11(4)(b) is of at least equal significance to 11(4)(a) in setting the maximum amount of any financial penalty so it appears to us inconsistent that its exercise is subject to negative procedure.

11.In our report on the Online Safety Bill, we discussed a power to set the definition of “qualifying worldwide revenue” which term was used in that Bill as “turnover” is in this: to partially determine the maximum level of financial penalty for breach of statutory duty. We concluded, noting precedent in the Product Security and Telecommunications Infrastructure Act 2022, that the definition should be set in regulations subject to affirmative procedure because it went to the “highly significant matter of the level of financial penalties”. The close similarity to setting out how turnover is to be determined in setting a maximum financial penalty is in our view clear.

12.The Memorandum does not seek to justify the use of negative procedure for exercise of the power in clause 11(4)(b). It is concerning that instead it wrongly suggests that the power to set how turnover is determined is subject to affirmative procedure.

title: Bell 505 achieves over 700 flight hours with blended SAF : The Daily Digest
description:
In Germany, Bell Textron announced that a single, dedicated Bell 505 has surpassed 700 flight hours using blended sustainable aviation fuel.
In March 2022, Bell announced its collaboration with Safran Helicopter Engines to explore technical performance and economic impacts of sustainable aviation fuel on the Bell 505 powered by the Arrius 2R engine.
Nearly one year after the announcement, the Bell 505 became the first-ever single engine helicopter to fly with 100% SAF during a demonstration flight, the firm said.
Since July 2022, Bell has accumulated over 700 flight hours using blended SAF on a single Bell 505 helicopter at the Bell Training Academy.
Assessments of engine operability and aircraft performance as well as engine inspections have yielded positive results to date, the company added.
text:
In Germany, Bell Textron announced that a single, dedicated Bell 505 has surpassed 700 flight hours using blended sustainable aviation fuel.

In March 2022, Bell announced its collaboration with Safran Helicopter Engines to explore technical performance and economic impacts of sustainable aviation fuel on the Bell 505 powered by the Arrius 2R engine. Nearly one year after the announcement, the Bell 505 became the first-ever single engine helicopter to fly with 100% SAF during a demonstration flight, the firm said.

Since July 2022, Bell has accumulated over 700 flight hours using blended SAF on a single Bell 505 helicopter at the Bell Training Academy. Assessments of engine operability and aircraft performance as well as engine inspections have yielded positive results to date, the company added.

title: Partnership between Vibra Energia and the government of Bahia: Salvador Airport ...
description:
O uso do SAF é considerado hoje a forma mais rápida e prática de reduzir as emissões da aviação comercial.
Operação diária no Aeroporto de Salvador com combustível sustentável A operação inaugurada no Aeroporto de Salvador não se limita a voos simbólicos ou experimentais.
A companhia também avança em negociações para expandir a oferta de SAF para outros estados e aeroportos.
Impactos ambientais do combustível sustentável (SAF) O impacto ambiental do SAF é a principal razão para sua adoção global.
Com a operação já em curso, outros aeroportos podem observar o modelo adotado em Salvador para replicá-lo em suas estruturas.
text:
O Aeroporto de Salvador inicia abastecimento regular com combustível sustentável da Vibra Energia, marcando um avanço no uso de SAF no Brasil e impulsionando a aviação de baixo carbono com ganhos ambientais significativos

On November 26th, 2025, Salvador International Airport tornou-se o primeiro do Brasil a abastecer voos comerciais com sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) provided by Vibra Energy. A operação inaugural representa um marco inédito para a aviação brasileira e um avanço significativo na agenda de decarbonization of air transport. A iniciativa envolve rotas regulares operadas com uma mistura de 10% de SAF e 90% de querosene tradicional, já sendo aplicada nos voos diários para Brasília e São Paulo.

Por que o SAF representa um avanço imediato para o Brasil

De acordo com as informações divulgadas pela empresa e pelo governo da Bahia, o uso do combustível sustentável pode reduzir até 80% of greenhouse gas emissions ao longo do ciclo de vida do produto. Além disso, a prestação desse serviço coloca Salvador como referência nacional ao se tornar o primeiro aeroporto brasileiro a ter um fornecimento constante de SAF para voos comerciais.

O uso do SAF é considerado hoje a forma mais rápida e prática de reduzir as emissões da aviação comercial. Isso ocorre porque o combustível sustentável pode ser utilizado em aeronaves convencionais sem exigir qualquer modificação técnica ou substituição de infraestrutura aeroportuária. Esse aspecto torna o combustível um aliado estratégico para acelerar a transição energética do setor aéreo.

O SAF fornecido pela Vibra Energy é produzido a partir de resíduos renováveis, como óleos usados, gorduras residuais e restos da agroindústria. Por utilizar materiais de baixo impacto ambiental, o ciclo de vida do produto emite menos carbono, o que resulta na redução significativa de gases de efeito estufa ao ser comparado ao querosene fóssil.

A certificação internacional aplicada ao combustível assegura rastreabilidade e comprovação de sustentabilidade. Isso significa que a origem da matéria-prima, o processo de produção e o transporte são verificados por entidades independentes, garantindo credibilidade aos resultados ambientais apresentados.

Operação diária no Aeroporto de Salvador com combustível sustentável

A operação inaugurada no Aeroporto de Salvador não se limita a voos simbólicos ou experimentais. Em vez disso, estabelece um padrão diário, com dois voos abastecidos regularmente com a mistura de 10% de SAF. Essa constância demonstra que o mercado brasileiro está preparado para integrar o combustível sustentável à rotina operacional da aviação.

O fornecimento inicial previsto para a fase de implementação chega a alguns milhões de litros, destinados exclusivamente para as rotas que partem da capital baiana. Isso demonstra que há planejamento de longo prazo, e não apenas projetos pontuais.

A Vibra Energy, que é responsável por abastecer mais de 90 aeroportos no país, estruturou sua cadeia logística para garantir o fornecimento contínuo do combustível sustentável. Como a empresa foi a primeira a disponibilizar SAF comercialmente no Brasil, Salvador se tornou o local ideal para iniciar a operação regular.

A companhia também avança em negociações para expandir a oferta de SAF para outros estados e aeroportos. Caso esse processo evolua, Salvador pode se transformar em um polo nacional de abastecimento sustentável, incentivando a expansão da aviação verde no país.

Impactos ambientais do combustível sustentável (SAF)

O impacto ambiental do SAF é a principal razão para sua adoção global. Mesmo com apenas 10% de mistura, há uma redução perceptível nas emissões de carbono. Quando utilizado em proporções maiores — o que é tecnicamente possível — o benefício se torna ainda mais expressivo, aproximando a aviação das metas globais estabelecidas por organismos internacionais.

Estudos indicam que o combustível sustentável pode reduzir até 80% das emissões de CO₂, dependendo da matéria-prima utilizada no processo produtivo. Essa redução considera todo o ciclo de vida do produto, desde a produção até a queima nos motores.

Para Salvador, a operação cria oportunidades de desenvolvimento econômico e ambiental. A cidade já é reconhecida como um polo turístico e logístico, e agora reforça o seu papel estratégico em iniciativas de inovação e sustentabilidade.

Para o Brasil, a iniciativa representa um avanço alinhado às metas de redução de emissões assumidas internacionalmente. A aviação é um setor conhecido por sua dificuldade de descarbonização, e o SAF desponta como a alternativa mais eficaz no curto e médio prazo.

Aeroporto de Salvador como referência nacional em aviação sustentável

Ao inaugurar essa operação, o Aeroporto Internacional de Salvador se posiciona como pioneiro no país e reforça sua relevância no cenário nacional. A iniciativa soma-se a projetos que já vinham sendo implementados no terminal, incluindo sistemas de eficiência energética, modernização da infraestrutura e práticas sustentáveis de gestão.

Ser o primeiro aeroporto brasileiro a oferecer abastecimento regular com combustível sustentável é mais do que um título simbólico — é um reconhecimento da capacidade técnica, da articulação institucional e do compromisso com a agenda climática.

Com a operação já em curso, outros aeroportos podem observar o modelo adotado em Salvador para replicá-lo em suas estruturas. A experiência prática facilitará a elaboração de políticas públicas, ajustes regulatórios e incentivos fiscais que favoreçam o uso do SAF em todo o país.

À medida que a oferta e a demanda crescem, o custo tende a diminuir, tornando o combustível sustentável mais competitivo e ampliando seu uso no setor aéreo.

Desafios para o avanço do SAF no país

Apesar dos benefícios ambientais, a ampliação do uso do SAF enfrenta desafios. O principal deles é o custo de produção, que ainda é superior ao do querosene convencional. Como o mercado brasileiro está em fase inicial, o volume disponível também é limitado.

Outro ponto relevante é a necessidade de políticas públicas específicas, capazes de estimular a produção nacional e reduzir a dependência de importações. Incentivos tributários, financiamentos e parcerias entre empresas e governos são fundamentais para impulsionar a cadeia produtiva.

A operação em Salvador, contudo, mostra que mesmo com os desafios, é possível estruturar um modelo viável e tecnicamente seguro.

A relevância do uso de SAF para o futuro da aviação brasileira

A operação iniciada no Aeroporto Internacional de Salvador representa um marco decisivo para o setor aéreo. O uso do SAF fornece benefícios ambientais comprovados, reforça a competitividade do país no cenário internacional e demonstra que a transição energética na aviação já está em andamento.

Ao adotar o combustível sustentável de forma regular, Salvador estabelece uma referência para todo o território nacional. A iniciativa demonstra que a inovação ambiental pode caminhar ao lado da operação comercial, mantendo a segurança, a eficiência e a regularidade dos voos.

The advance of Vibra Energy como fornecedora do SAF reforça o protagonismo nacional na distribuição de combustíveis mais limpos, abrindo caminho para que outras empresas ampliem seus investimentos.

title: Hazardex Live
description:
The winners of the industry’s most prestigious awards will be announced during a Gala Dinner at Hazardex Live 2026 on 25 February in Harrogate.
The competition is open to all Hazardex journal, eNewsletter, social media, and website readers and users * 2.
The project also involved the construction, completion, and commissioning of a Steam Methane Reforming Hydrogen Plant.
Website: https://www.hazardexonthenet.net/article/215017/Spot-the-robot--dog--helps-reactivate-crane-at-nuclear-facility.aspx -- f. Statera Energy – Thurrock Storage, the UK’s largest battery energy storage system Thurrock Storage, the UK’s largest battery energy storage system (BESS) developed by Statera Energy, is now energised and delivering electricity to the grid.
The landmark 300MW battery storage site is capable of powering up to 680,000 homes with instantaneous power over two hours.
text:
A total of 30 nominees have been shortlisted across five categories for the Hazardex Awards 2026, designed to recognise excellence in the hazardous area sector. The winners of the industry’s most prestigious awards will be announced during a Gala Dinner at Hazardex Live 2026 on 25 February in Harrogate. Here, you can find the nominees for Plant Upgrade & Innovation - Sponsored by C&P Engineering. Submit your votes now!

Below, you can find the details of the six nominees for Category 5: Plant Upgrade & Innovation – Sponsored by C&P Engineering Services

An operator that has successfully implemented projects or equipment to enhance safety, efficiency, and technological innovation in their hazardous areas.

Voting closes on 1 February.

Voting rules:

* 1. The competition is open to all Hazardex journal, eNewsletter, social media, and website readers and users

* 2. Voters register their votes by fully completing all fields and use an email from a business address only

* 3. Voters are limited to one vote per category

* 4. Nominees are not permitted to vote for their own company/organisation

* 5. All votes will remain confidential

The nominees for the Plant Upgrade & Innovation Award are:

a. Essar Energy Transition – installation of hydrogen-ready furnace at Stanlow Refinery

EET Fuels (the trading name of Essar Oil) successfully completed the installation and connection of a new hydrogen-ready furnace to the refinery system at its Stanlow site in Ellesmere Port, Cheshire. Following delivery at the Stanlow site in August 2022, the hydrogen-ready furnace is now fully operational and will be capable of running on 100% refinery off gas (ROG), a blend of ROG and hydrogen fuel, or 100% hydrogen. The furnace will be conventionally fuelled until 2028 when it will transition to using 100% low-carbon hydrogen, produced by EET Hydrogen’s HPP1 plant. Installation of the hydrogen-ready furnace significantly progresses EET Fuels’ ambition to eliminate 95% (around 2 million tonnes of carbon dioxide a year) of its carbon emissions by 2030.

Website: https://www.hazardexonthenet.net/article/215342/Essar-Energy-Transition-s-hydrogen-ready-furnace-now-powering-EET-Fuels--Stanlow-Site.aspx

--

b. Equinor – deployment of autonomous robotics systems across all refinery sites in Norway

Equinor’s innovation team in Norway has successfully deployed autonomous robotics systems to conduct routine tasks such as monitoring and inspection. The robots use onboard sensors to conduct acoustic, visual and leak detection while also allowing for collection of routine sample points and taking them to a non-hazardous location for testing. The main purpose of the project is to remove personnel from being exposed to hazards in process areas during these routine tasks.

The innovation of this project is not just in the utilisation of robots, but the process Equinor went through, along with it project partners, for determining the suitability of non-ATEX certified or assessed robots to be used in Zone 2 areas. Equinor identified that due to gaps in the current methodologies used for certification of systems for use in hazardous areas, it is not always clear how to apply hazardous area requirements to these systems but also that existing certifications may have gaps to be able to determine that all ignition risks have been defined and managed to acceptable levels. This approach has satisfied equivalence to certification and satisfied all Equinor’s procedural requirements for deployment of equipment in hazardous areas, as with any other devices. Equinor is now supporting DNV in spearheading a Joint Industry Project with multiple operators and robotics companies to develop a recommended practice for assessment of robotics systems for use in hazardous areas.

--

c. ExxonMobil – £800m investment in Fawley Petrochemical complex

Representing a more than £800m investment, ExxonMobil has constructed a new low-sulphur diesel facility at its Fawley refinery. The energy major said increasing low-sulphur diesel production at Fawley by 40 percent should reduce imports into Britain by a quarter while helping to meet demand from sectors including heavy transport, emergency response, agriculture and industry. The project also involved the construction, completion, and commissioning of a Steam Methane Reforming Hydrogen Plant. The new hydrogen plant builds on over 50 years of experience with hydrogen production onsite and could enable the production of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) as the energy transition evolves.

--

d. INEOS – £30 million investment at Hull manufacturing site to cut emissions by 75%

INEOS has completed a major £30 million investment at its Hull manufacturing site, converting the facility to run on clean-burning hydrogen instead of natural gas. The result is a 75% cut in carbon emissions – the equivalent of taking around 160,000 petrol cars off the road and a huge step towards INEOS’ net zero commitment, well ahead of 2050, the company says. This investment will deliver a transformational step change improvement in the site’s product carbon footprint, INEOS said. The hydrogen used at the site is produced as a co-product from existing manufacturing processes, a model which INEOS believes can be replicated across the industry.

Website: https://www.hazardexonthenet.net/article/216728/INEOS-invests--30-million-to-cut-emissions-at-Hull-site-by-75-.aspx

--

e. Nuclear Decommissioning Authority – use of Spot the robot "dog" to reactivate equipment at Dounreay nuclear site

Spot, the robot "dog," assisted personnel in Dounreay’s Fuel Cycle Area by reactivating a crucial building crane in a reprocessing plant. The crane had been deactivated at the switchboard in 2023 due to concerns about the ageing asset at the nuclear site. Safety restrictions prohibited human interaction with the switchboard, which further delayed its reactivation. However, the facility required the crane for waste shipment and for ongoing decommissioning efforts. Following consultations with NRS, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Nuclear Decommissioning Authority, it was decided to use Spot for the task. As the site’s Spot was not equipped with an “arm” handling device, the team asked the Robotics and Artificial Intelligence Collaboration (RAICo) for support. After conducting a week of trials on a non-live switch mock-up in a nearby substation storeroom, Spot used a gripped pole to flip the switch, successfully restoring power to the crane.

Website: https://www.hazardexonthenet.net/article/215017/Spot-the-robot--dog--helps-reactivate-crane-at-nuclear-facility.aspx

--

f. Statera Energy – Thurrock Storage, the UK’s largest battery energy storage system

Thurrock Storage, the UK’s largest battery energy storage system (BESS) developed by Statera Energy, is now energised and delivering electricity to the grid. The landmark 300MW battery storage site is capable of powering up to 680,000 homes with instantaneous power over two hours. Thurrock Storage can respond rapidly to changes on the grid, delivering its full output of up to 600MWh within seconds. Strategically located close to London, Thurrock Storage will play a significant role in maintaining the UK’s energy security. It facilitates the immediate and efficient deployment of energy directly where it is most needed, significantly enhancing grid stability and resilience. The site is also located immediately north of the former Tilbury coal power station, transforming the site’s legacy to enable the clean energy transition.

Website: https://www.hazardexonthenet.net/article/217166/Statera-Energy-powers-up-UK-s-largest-battery-storage-site.aspx

--
