For a country with limited land, devoting this much space to next-generation energy is a signal: Singapore sees Jurong Island not just as an industrial district, but as a platform for its national energy transition.

Testbeds as a competitive advantage

Three of the newly announced partnerships center on experimental platforms that allow companies to prove, validate, and scale low-carbon technologies under real operating conditions.

The Sustainable Tropical Data Center Testbed is among the most notable. JTC and the National University of Singapore are preparing to launch Phase 2 of the testbed, located directly on Jurong Island. With AI workloads straining power grids worldwide, Singapore is planning a 700-MW low-carbon data center park on the island. The testbed will allow operators to pilot immersion cooling, direct-chip cooling, smart energy-management systems, and AI-optimized workload distribution — all critical for reducing heat and energy use in a tropical environment.

Another major effort is A*STAR’s Low Carbon Technology Translational Testbed (LCT3), developed with Surbana Jurong. LCT3 will provide a turnkey environment for piloting industrial decarbonization solutions — from carbon-capture systems to low-emission thermal processes — with the engineering support needed to move from experimentation to commercial deployment.

Singapore is also planning a renewable-energy microgrid testbed in collaboration with Keppel. This system will explore advanced demand-response controls as well as thermal-energy networks capable of redistributing cooling loads across multiple industrial facilities — an approach that could reduce overall electricity demand significantly.

Hydrogen is the spotlight

Aster announced one of the most significant industrial investments: a SG$195 million (US$150 million) hydrogen-ready integrated gas turbine for its Jurong Island facility. The turbine will allow Aster to generate its own low-carbon electricity and export surplus to Singapore’s national grid.

Aster also signed an MOU with Air Liquide to explore producing low-carbon hydrogen using auto-thermal reforming (ATR) paired with carbon capture. ATR is one of the few commercially viable pathways capable of achieving high capture rates — a key requirement if hydrogen is to play a meaningful role in Singapore’s energy system.

Singapore’s National Hydrogen Strategy identifies hydrogen and hydrogen-derived fuels as long-term options for power generation, heavy industry, aviation, and maritime bunkering. Domestic production will not replace imports, but it could become an important complement, especially for industrial users on Jurong Island.

Startups, talent needed in industrial decarbonization

In a move that differentiates Jurong Island from traditional industrial parks, JTC is partnering with Third Derivative (D3), a global climate-tech accelerator supported by the Rocky Mountain Institute (RMI). The collaboration will connect more than 280 cleantech startups with large industrial players on Jurong Island.

For startups developing technologies that need industrial-scale testing, access to Jurong Island’s infrastructure could be transformative. For industry players, the partnership creates a pipeline of early-stage innovation that can be tested and adapted quickly.

Singapore’s strategy recognizes that new infrastructure is only as effective as the workforce that operates it. JTC and NUS are co-developing training modules, internships, and a potential specialization in industrial decarbonization and sustainable digital infrastructure to prepare future engineers and technicians.

Advario Singapore will work with Workforce Singapore to redesign roles and upskill 150 employees for handling emerging fuels such as ammonia — a critical capability as global shipping lines explore ammonia-powered propulsion.

A new blueprint for industrial regions worldwide

As older energy and chemicals hubs in the United States, Europe, and Asia grapple with decarbonization, Singapore is turning Jurong Island into a showcase of what a coordinated industrial transition can look like. Singapore is also looking at nuclear energy in its mix, because currently it generates 95% of its electricity from natural gas. And less than 3% of its energy comes from renewable source, particularly solar. The island nation is, however, actively expanding its solar capacity and plans to import wind energy from Vietnam, solar from Vietnam, and hydropower from Malaysia.

JTC chief executive Jacqueline Poh summarized the approach: “Strategic collaboration across the ecosystem is essential to accelerating the transformation we envision for Jurong Island.”

title: Busy building ties and trust throughout the region | Defence
description:
“With this increased capability comes a need for increased interoperability as partnerships and coalitions meet the needs of the Indo-Pacific region,” Major Jones said.
“It was a great opportunity to introduce the way the Australian Defence Force approaches aviation safety and share some of our lessons learned.
Cambodia is one of 13 countries in the Indo-Pacific region that IPE will travel to this year to participate in workshops, engagements and knowledge exchanges.
This year marks the fourth year of this training program, which has become a key feature of the Indo-Pacific Endeavour Program.
The exercise saw approximately 1600 Australia Defence Force personnel deployed abroad in the Indo-Pacific Region, the largest commitment in nearly 20 years.
text:
Advancing women’s participation in peace processes

Wednesday, 26 November 2025 - 11:00 AM

The Australian Government co-hosted two Women Peace and Security (WPS) activities with Vietnam in Hanoi last week as part of Indo-Pacific Endeavour 2025.

Representatives from Australia’s Department of Defence and Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade met with the Vietnam People’s Army to share experiences in a bilateral seminar on implementing a Women Peace and Security National Action Plan.

Together, Australia and Vietnam then co-hosted a minilateral Women Peace and Security seminar with participants from Cambodia, Laos and UN Women, as well as observers from Canada, Japan and New Zealand. The seminar focused on enabling activities for the full and meaningful participation of women in peace processes, including the consideration of effective recruitment and retention policies, as well as employing gender advisors.

Head of the visiting Australian delegation, Colonel Karen Such, said this year marked 25 years since the adoption of the UN Security Council Resolution (UNSCR) 1325 on Women, Peace and Security.

UNSCR 1325 recognises the disproportionate impact of conflict on women and girls, and affirms the vital role women play in preventing conflict, building peace and supporting recovery efforts.

“Despite progress since Resolution 1325, the transformative potential of WPS remains underrealised. As such, it was incredibly meaningful to see Australia and Vietnam collaborate to continue to push the boundaries of WPS in a regional context,” Colonel Such said.

Australia is grateful to Vietnam for hosting these important seminars and greatly values working with Vietnam to build a more inclusive, peaceful, stable and prosperous Indo-Pacific.

Aviation safety on the agenda in Thailand

Wednesday, 19 November 2025 - 15:30 PM

A Mobile Training Team from the Australian Defence Aviation Safety Authority recently completed a three-day Aviation Safety Training Seminar in Bangkok, Thailand.

The four-member team from the Education and Training Directorate delivered a tailored program on topics designed to strengthen bilateral engagement and aviation safety knowledge as part of Indo-Pacific Endeavour 25 (IPE25).

Participants included representatives from all three services of the Royal Thai military, with ranks ranging from group captain to pilot officer.

Key subjects covered included aviation safety management systems, human factors, aviation risk management, data collection and analysis, and the aviation safety investigation process.

Seminar lead Major Andrew Jones said air safety in the region was becoming increasingly important as regional partners expanded capabilities within complex environments to meet the needs of self-defence, as well as providing support to humanitarian and disaster response activities.

“With this increased capability comes a need for increased interoperability as partnerships and coalitions meet the needs of the Indo-Pacific region,” Major Jones said.

“It was a great opportunity to introduce the way the Australian Defence Force approaches aviation safety and share some of our lessons learned.

“It was also a great opportunity to network with our partners in the region on an increasingly important and complex area of work.”

Deputy Defence Attaché at the Australian Embassy in Bangkok Wing Commander Fernando Lay said it was fantastic to see the Australian contingent in Thailand engaging with counterparts.

“Indo-Pacific Endeavour’s Aviation Safety Seminar continues to strengthen bonds between Australian and Thailand while sharing expertise to enhance collective aviation safety knowledge,” he said.

Collaborate to innovate

Wednesday, 5 November 2025 - 14:16 PM

As part of Indo-Pacific Endeavour 2025, the ADF Drone Racing Team showed off their exciting sport and spoke about defence innovation through uncrewed systems programs at the Malaysian Ministry of Defence (Kementerian Pertahanan Malaysia).

Team leader, Squadron Leader Josh Vicino, touched on the importance of adaptability and innovation in defence and associated industries to meet new challenges.

An active ADF reservist working in the defence industry, Squadron Leader Vicino is a qualified electronics engineer who is helping to build the next generation of airborne intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance platforms.

“Our security and prosperity relies on creative, curious and innovative people thinking outside the box,” Squadron Leader Vicino said.

“Security challenges evolve rapidly, and technology refresh cycles are getting shorter and shorter. We need to out-think and out-pace our adversaries.”

On the sidelines of the drone display, Australian officials met with representatives of STRIDE, the Malaysian Defence Science & Technology Research Institute.

This engagement paves the way for collaboration between Australia and Malaysia’s defence research, design and manufacturing sectors.

“We look forward to working closely with our Australian friends,” a Malaysian Ministry of Defence spokesman said.

“Our people are smart, creative and committed to protecting the stability of our region. Together they can achieve great things.”

Indo-Pacific Endeavour Chief of Staff, Group Captain Steven Henry, said drone racing was a fantastic way to introduce people to the exciting world of uncrewed systems and STEM activities.

“The ADF Drone Racing Team have put on a fantastic display and energised our conversations around innovation with our Malaysian counterparts,” he said.

Maintaining a secure region at the Oceans Dialogue in Vietnam

Monday, 27 October 2025 - 12:16 PM

The Indo-Pacific Endeavour Program sent a delegate from the National Security and Resilience Branch to Hanoi to participate in the Sixth Vietnam-Australia Oceans Dialogue.

Department of Defence delegate Louis Polkinghorne said the Dialogue provided a great opportunity to discuss strategic developments in the Indo-Pacific region and South China Sea, as well as our bilateral Australia-Vietnam maritime security cooperation.

The Dialogue provided the opportunity to find common ground on opportunities to strengthen peace and stability in the region, including through upholding international law and the freedom of navigation. Levering these opportunities would enable Australia and Vietnam to further strengthen the bilateral relationship and promote transparency and cooperation between the two countries.

It was refreshing to see like-minded representatives sharing their concerns about escalating national security risks in the maritime space. Vietnam was eager to exchange experiences with Australia and learn about Australia’s resilience-based approaches to protect undersea cables, Mr Polkinghorne said.

“I was impressed with attendees’ openness and willingness to discuss contemporary maritime security challenges in the South China Sea and honoured to work with a trusted international partner,” he said.

“It’s been a real privilege to be involved in this dialogue and see firsthand how person-to-person connection drives diplomacy efforts to maintain our peaceful and prosperous region.”

IPE hosts delegates from across the region

Tuesday, 21 October 2025 - 15:00 PM

The Indo-Pacific Endeavour (IPE) program was pleased to host South-East Asian delegations for the Australasian Military Medicine Association (AMMA) Conference in Adelaide.

Nineteen representatives from Bangladesh, Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand and Vietnam converged on the Adelaide Convention Centre from October 17-19.

Major General Nishat Jubaida, the only female two-star general in the Bangladesh Army, said she was delighted to see female representation among senior leadership across the many nations represented at the AMMA conference.

Senior medical officers from each nation attending the conference held talks with ADF Surgeon General Rear Admiral Sonya Bennett.

Delegates also joined the AMMA program in specialised workshops that aligned with their respective medical specialisations.

Lieutenant Wan Nurul Naszeerah, from the Royal Brunei Land Forces, presented her research titled Listening to the Force – which uses artificial intelligence to categorise sentiment in health communications – at the conference.

In addition to military health personnel, the AMMA audience included civilian medical providers, contractors, state and federal health officials and emergency services personnel and academics.

The visiting IPE delegations were supported by IPE personnel and joined other host officers from the ADF’s Joint Health Command who have experience working alongside military health experts in South-East Asian nations.

Having deployed to Vietnam on IPE earlier this year, Captain Brendan Nguyen, a psychologist from 3rd Health Battalion, was on hand to assist the Vietnamese delegation alongside fellow Vietnamese-Australian Major Jacob Choi. Both members said it was a privilege to host officers from their parents’ country of birth, giving them a sense of meaningful purpose.

Find out more about other IPE activities here, including Captain Nguyen’s IPE work in Vietnam earlier this year to deliver a mental health pilot package.

Developing a peacekeeping capability

Friday, 17 October 2025 - 15:30 PM

The Indo-Pacific Endeavour (IPE) program brought a delegation from the Lao People’s Army to Canberra to observe UN-accredited peace operations training, supporting Laos’ interest in developing its peacekeeping capability.

Department of Defence policy advisor to IPE25, Jordan Anderton, said the visit gave the delegation valuable insights into how Australia conducts UN-accredited training at the Peace Operations Training Centre (POTC).

The delegation watched participants from Thailand, the Philippines and Timor-Leste undertaking the United Nations Staff Officer Course and UN Military Observer Course at the Majura Range Training Area.

Ms Anderton said the simulated learning allowed the delegation to see role players in scenarios drawn from real UN missions, and Australia’s unique approach to preparing students for UN peacekeeping operations.

“Students learn how to conduct the [UN Military Decision-Making Process] UN MDMP and planning for activities for a UN mission. They also use a [simulation] SIM virtual vehicle patrol and avatar, simulating a military observer patrol and interactions with local people,” she said.

The program is a mandated peacekeeper observer’s course that prepares ADF and international personnel for the complexities of UN peacekeeping missions.

Participants were tested on critical skills including negotiation, mediation and dispute resolution, all under simulated operational conditions.

“The delegation was impressed with the training and said that the course appeared to prepare its participants to meet the complex situations and challenges of being deployed on a UN mission,” Ms Anderton said.

“It was great to have Lao representatives visit us and observe our courses. This visit is a concrete example of our growing Defence relationship with the Lao People’s Army.”

Strengthening people-to-people links through IPE25

Wednesday, 8 October 2025 - 16:00 PM

Australian Defence Adviser to Sri Lanka and Maldives Colonel Amanda Johnston reflects on IPE25 conducting knowledge exchanges in the north-east Indian Ocean:

Hot on the heels of a high-level visit by our Deputy Prime Minister and Defence Minister Richard Marles to Sri Lanka and Maldives, Australian Defence Force personnel were back in the north-east Indian Ocean region to exchange knowledge and build people-to-people links through Indo-Pacific Endeavour (IPE) 2025.

Australia’s 2024 National Defence Strategy highlighted the strategic importance of the north-east Indian Ocean and directed increased defence engagement with countries like Sri Lanka and Maldives. IPE is a practical symbol of the deepening defence relationships with both.

In Sri Lanka, IPE included a number of different activities, all focused on knowledge-sharing. Army Engineers from the 2nd Combat Engineer Regiment visited Sri Lanka’s School of Military Engineering for a workshop on humanitarian demining and search operations, while ADF personnel were embedded in a US-led multilateral exercise, Pacific Angel, to participate in subject matter expert exchanges in military medicine, mass casualty evacuation, aeromedical evacuation, and combat search and rescue operations.

Additionally, Australia led a bilateral knowledge exchange focused on maritime surveillance using the former-RAAF KA350 aircraft that Australia gifted to Sri Lanka in 2024. In a neat twist, RAAF Squadron Leader Glenn Canfield, who delivered the KA350 to Sri Lanka last October, returned to the island for a professional exchange with Sri Lanka Air Force’s 3 (Maritime) Squadron. The Sri Lanka Air Force pilots were thrilled to have the chance to pick Squadron Leader Canfield’s brain on everything about the aircraft and its maritime surveillance role.

Across the Laccadive Sea, ADF personnel also visited the Maldives for workshops focused on human capital. Royal Australian Navy Chaplain Mogamat Majidih Essa reached ‘celebrity imam’ status delivering televised Friday prayers and leading several command sessions in mental health and wellbeing, while staff from the Indo-Pacific Centre for Military Law and ADF workforce modellers guided Maldives National Defence Force (MNDF) staff through discussions on their respective areas.

Commander IPE Brigadier Jen Harris also visited the Maldives and met with senior MNDF leaders and hosted a gender, peace and security forum.

As the only named activity on the ADF calendar for both countries, IPE is a key engagement activity that enables us to pursue specific National Defence Strategy objectives, in particular raising the visibility of the ADF in the north-east Indian Ocean and deepening the people-to-people links. IPE is a practical symbol of our deepening defence relationships with north-east Indian Ocean countries and demonstrates Australia’s commitment to a safer and more secure maritime backyard.

We look forward to IPE26!

Engaging with counterparts in Cambodia

Monday, 29 September 2025 - 12:00 PM

ADF personnel from the Indo-Pacific Endeavour (IPE) program and the Defence Section from the Australian Embassy to Cambodia visited the Multi-National Training Centre at Ream Naval Base, Cambodia, to collaborate with Royal Cambodian Navy personnel on maritime security and military diving capabilities.

Lieutenant Colonel Paul Henry, who led the IPE contingent, said it was great to be back in Cambodia, connecting with colleagues and workshopping ideas to develop capabilities in particular areas of mutual interest.

“Our team was accompanied by Australian Ambassador to Cambodia, H.E. Derek Yip, and we were fortunate to meet with the Commander of Ream Naval Base, Rear Admiral Mey Dina, to discuss IPE support to the Royal Cambodian Navy in the areas of maritime law, maritime security, and development of a military diving capability,” Lieutenant Colonel Henry said.

The team also met with the Commander of the National Committee for Maritime Security Tactical Headquarters, Rear Admiral Ly Huot, to discuss future collaboration on naval interdiction and military diving training for members of the Royal Cambodian Navy.

“The Royal Cambodian Navy has a strong interest in enhancing its capabilities in these specialist fields. We will continue to engage in this area, including considering providing Cambodia with diving equipment,” Lieutenant Colonel Henry said.

“Australia is keen to collaborate with our neighbours in the Indo-Pacific region on improving maritime security and our collective ability to respond to maritime security events, including on humanitarian and disaster relief operations.”

While in Cambodia, the IPE team also visited the Institute for Peacekeeping, Mine Clearance and ERW (IPMEC) in Phnom Penh.

The team discussed future collaboration with Royal Cambodian Armed Forces (RCAF) personnel on training Cambodian peacekeepers for UN operations, including the Comprehensive Protection of Civilians, Gender Peace and Security, and English language training.

ADF personnel also met with a number of RCAF students currently undergoing training courses at IPMEC. The RCAF has a long history of involvement in peacekeeping operations, with more than 10,000 RCAF members deploying as peacekeepers since 2006.

Cambodia is one of 13 countries in the Indo-Pacific region that IPE will travel to this year to participate in workshops, engagements and knowledge exchanges. IPE aims to strengthen Australia’s regional relationships and build on trusted partnerships that have been developed and nurtured since the IPE program began in 2017.

Strengthening partnerships across the Indo-Pacific

Monday, 22 September 2025 - 15:30 PM

An update from Commander IPE Jen Harris:

Australia’s Indo-Pacific Endeavour (IPE) program is in full swing, with September seeing engagements across the breadth of the region. Teams travelled to the north-east Indian Ocean, renewing valued friendships in Sri Lanka and the Maldives. Closer to home, we have been catching up with colleagues in Brunei and Timor-Leste.

In Sri Lanka, we have focused on maritime surveillance, search and rescue, military medicine and military engineering. IPE activities were designed to complement the regional multinational activity Pacific Angel, co-hosted by the Sri Lanka Air Force and the US Air Force. Pacific Angel focuses on humanitarian and disaster relief, and our teams undertook valuable training in emergency medical and evacuation procedures.

People were central to the program in the Maldives this year, working together to develop workforce modelling capability, and sharing knowledge and experience in military justice and gender, peace and security. A highlight was the return of Royal Australian Navy Chaplain Imam Mogamat Essa, who led faith-based engagements focused on the spiritual wellbeing and mental resilience of our forces.

In Brunei, IPE coincided with the 80th anniversary commemorations for Australia’s Operation Oboe landings for the liberation of Borneo. Australia and Brunei Darussalam enjoy a longstanding defence partnership stretching back to World War 2. Unique to this year, IPE ran concurrent with Exercise Penguin, a biennial maritime security exercise between our two nations. A Royal Australian Air Force P-8A Poseidon and Royal Australian Navy Anzac-class frigate HMAS Ballarat supported the exercise. These two parallel programs represent the breadth and depth of the relationship

During the week of IPE activities, Australian and Bruneian participants exchanged knowledge in the areas of defensive cyber, military law and workforce planning. Flight Lieutenant Imam Abdul Kader made his fifth visit to Brunei. During a five-day religious engagement program, Imam Kader delivered a presentation on emotional intelligence to youth leaders, providing practical demonstrations of the support chaplains provide in the field.

At the core of all these engagements are people-to-people connections, reinforcing the latticework of trusted partnerships that characterise this region we call home. We have seen the power of dialogue and knowledge sharing firsthand, especially when founded on mutual respect and understanding. It has been a true privilege to play a small part in the incredible work our Defence and whole of Australian Government colleagues do every day to cultivate these partnerships. Thank you.

IPE25 trilateral English Language Teacher Training strengthens ties

Tuesday, 9 September 2025 - 12:30 PM

Commander IPE25 Brigadier Jennifer Harris reflects on her visit to Hanoi this week for the opening of the English Language Teacher Training program:

It’s an absolute privilege to be in Hanoi this week, representing the Australian Defence Force and the Indo-Pacific Endeavour Program, to open this year’s English Language Teacher Training program.

Teachers from Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia will undertake a week of intensive teacher training.

Australian language specialists from the Defence International Training Centre, Captain Jen Hackney and Mr Chris Wilkinson, will deliver the training.

Indo-Pacific Endeavour, Australia’s flagship regional engagement activity, is pleased to be back at Vietnam’s Foreign Relations Department, continuing our enduring collaboration with our friends from Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia.

This annual training is a testament to the strength of our partnerships and our shared commitment to a peaceful, stable, and prosperous Indo-Pacific region – where state sovereignty is protected, international law is followed and nations can make decisions free from coercion.

We are proud to support this training package, investing in teachers, our greatest knowledge sharers. The investment you will make in the next five days will enhance our respective language capability, but also deepens the people-to-people links that are at the heart of our defence cooperation, building relationships founded on openness and mutual respect.

In a world of many languages, English continues to play a central role in facilitating multinational cooperation, peacekeeping operations and joint military exercises. English language teachers are essential to enabling stronger collaboration and enhancing mutual understanding across borders.

This year marks the fourth year of this training program, which has become a key feature of the Indo-Pacific Endeavour Program. Our sincere thanks to the Foreign Relations Department, which continues to host this important activity. Each iteration builds on the last, strengthening our shared capacity and reinforcing the bonds of friendship and trust between our nations.

The Australian Defence Force values the opportunity to work alongside our regional partners in building skills that support not only military effectiveness but also broader regional stability. Thank you to all the teachers and the trainers for the continued investment you make every day in building our future leaders.

Together, we are building a stronger, more connected Indo-Pacific.

Alon and Keris Woomera evolve into major military exercises

Wednesday, 3 September 2025 - 12:00 PM

Commander IPE 2025 Brigadier Jennifer Harris was in the Philippines last week for the final stages of Exercise Alon 25. The exercise saw approximately 1600 Australia Defence Force personnel deployed abroad in the Indo-Pacific Region, the largest commitment in nearly 20 years.

Since first being conducted as an amphibious landing activity with the Philippine Marines in 2023, Exercise Alon 25 has evolved to encompass comprehensive cooperation between the ADF and all services of the Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP).

Brigadier Harris said it was impressive to witness multi-domain cooperation between the ADF and the AFP, across air, land, maritime and special operations taskforces and elements, supported by Space and Cyber components.

“Exercise Alon grew out of Australia’s Indo-Pacific Endeavour (IPE) Program. This year’s iteration exemplifies the incredible growth in our partnership and it now stands alone as a key biennial joint activity between Australia and the Philippines,” she said.

Around 3600 personnel trained together between August 15 and 29 at locations around the islands of Palawan and Luzon.

This year’s Exercise Alon also included participation by the Royal Canadian Navy frigate HMCS Ville de Québec, and the United States Marine Corps’ Marine Rotation Force – Darwin, which included MV-22B Osprey tilt-rotor aircraft.

Exercise Alon is a biennial activity. In the alternate year, the ADF and the Indonesian National Armed Forces (TNI) train together in Exercise Keris Woomera, deepening bonds and military interoperability.

“It is impressive to see how the foundation laid by IPE has supported the growth and evolution of these two major standalone activities embedded into the training schedules of each country. Alon and Keris Woomera were Australia’s largest overseas military exercises in 2024 and 25,” Brigadier Harris said.

“These significant training activities successfully demonstrate Australia’s ability to force project into our region to support our key regional partners.”

The joint exercises not only improve military skills, demonstrate enhanced interoperability and strengthen defence diplomacy between participating countries – they build a spirit of mutual trust and are important steps in building strong cooperation to maintain regional stability.

Focus on resilience at regional security forum in Brisbane

Wednesday, 20 August 2025 - 15:30 PM

The IPE team was represented at the 2025 Indo-Pacific Environmental Security Forum (IPESF) in Brisbane last week.

Chief of Staff Group Captain Steve Henry led the team in welcoming counterparts from Bangladesh to the forum who were keen to discuss sustainable fuels as part of a broader collaboration with the Defence Energy Transition Office (DETO).

The overarching theme of the four-day conference was operational resilience. Day one focused on disaster resilience and how partnerships strengthen collective responses to disasters. Day two was focused on energy resilience during disasters. Day three was about systems thinking, community resilience and conflict prevention. Day four culminated in discussions and presentations around strategic partnerships and capability sharing.

Attending the conference, Squadron Leader Robert Bride said it brought together military and civilian agencies and regional experts from 21 countries to discuss non-traditional security threats, including lack of disaster preparedness; energy insecurity; climate-related environmental impacts; illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing; water insecurity; and energy transition, solutions and best practices.

The forum provided an invaluable opportunity to better understand emerging solutions and best practice in responding to these challenges.

“The IPESF is unique in that it brings military and civilian discussions to the forefront and showcases the need to have a whole-of-stakeholder approach to addressing disasters, oil spills, water scarcity, climate migration challenges, energy insecurity and other environmental security threats,” Squadron Leader Bride said.

Environmental security can be broadly defined as countering vulnerabilities caused by the abundance or scarcity of environmental resources and/or degradation.

“The IPESF provides an opportunity for civilian entities to gain a better understanding of the important work that militaries do to reduce risks to national security, better identify and map the military and civilian nexus, and for Defence forces to learn about innovative solutions that industry and educational institutions are implementing to combat the same or similar environmental security challenges,” Squadron Leader Bride said.

The Center for Excellence in Disaster Management and Humanitarian Assistance (CFE-DM), United States Indo-Pacific Command (USINDOPACOM) and Australian Defence Force, in partnership with the New Zealand Defence Force and the New Zealand Ministry of Defence, coordinated the 14th annual forum.

IPE planning kicks off in Dili

Friday, 11 July 2025 - 16:00 PM

Last week, IPE25 headquarters visited Dili, Timor-Leste, to meet with the Australian Defence Cooperation Program team in country to progress planning ahead of delivering the IPE25 program later this year.

This year IPE25 is looking forward to engaging with our friends in Timor-Leste for the Xanana Cosgrove Shield, an annual soccer match between the Timor-Leste Armed Forces (F-FDTL) and members of the Australian Defence Force that commemorates the anniversary of the INTERFET mission and honours the contributions of veterans to Timorese independence.

IPE25 is also looking forward to progressing our longstanding cooperation on gender, peace and security and faith-based engagement.

The Australian team is always keen to immerse ourselves in local culture of our Indo-Pacific neighbours and while in Dili we were privileged to visit the 27-metre high Cristo Rei of Dili (Christ the King of Dili) statue.

The IPE25 team looks forward to returning to Timor-Leste later in the year.

Commander IPE25 Brigadier Jennifer Harris

More from Commander IPE25 Brigadier Jennifer Harris

Thursday, 3 July 2025 - 13:00 PM

IPE was pleased to be able to deliver a two-day mental health pre-deployment training package to Vietnam People’s Army personnel soon to deploy on United Nations peacekeeping missions in Africa.

It was the first time Australia has delivered mental health training to Vietnamese military personnel and builds on an already significant relationship focused on pre-deployment training, education and cooperation for Vietnam’s peacekeepers.

The mental health pre-deployment training was delivered to medical personnel at Military Hospital 175 in Ho Chi Minh City in May. They will soon deploy to The UN Mission in South Sudan.

The training was also delivered to about 200 personnel from the Engineering Company Rotation 4 in Hanoi. The engineers will deploy to the UN Interim Security Force for Abyei.

I was honoured to address the company of engineers at Vietnam’s Department of Peacekeeping Operations in Hanoi and share my reflections on mental health and resilience as a veteran and fellow combat engineer.

We received positive feedback from the pilot training package and will be in a position to offer the pre-deployment mental health training into the future.

You can read more about the mental health training at these links:

Mental health training builds on Vietnamese ties | Defence;

Army psych values training first-hand in Vietnam | Defence

Hard-won lessons on military mental health | Defence

Message from Commander IPE25 Brigadier Jennifer Harris

Thursday, 3 July 2025 - 11:30 AM

It’s a privilege to command Indo-Pacific Endeavour (IPE) this year, as we commence the exciting 2025 program, which kicks off this month.

We have a great team drawing on incredible expertise from across Defence and broader government and interagency partners. The whole team is primed to turn planning into reality, engaging with our neighbours and friends in South-East Asia and the North-East Indian Ocean.

We are building a great schedule of activities to further strengthen our regional relationships and build on trusted partnerships that have been developed and nurtured since the IPE program began in 2017.

Over the next six months, subject matter experts will travel from Australia to participate in workshops, engagements and knowledge exchanges in Bangladesh, Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Maldives, the Philippines, Singapore, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Timor-Leste and Vietnam.

Bangladesh will open the program with members from Australia’s Defence Energy Transition Office and Bangladesh Air Force undertaking a knowledge exchange on the topic of sustainable aviation fuel and climate change. We look forward to sharing more information with you about that in the near future.

As well as travelling abroad, IPE will invite members from our partner nations to visit us here to take part in strategically important events and conferences. In August, partner nations will attend the Australian National University’s Malaysia Conference in Adelaide and the Indo-Pacific Environmental Security Forum in Brisbane.

As the National Defence Strategy 2024 made clear, Australia is committed to working with partners to build a region that is peaceful, stable, prosperous and respectful of sovereignty and international law.

IPE is a practical demonstration of the Australian Government’s commitment to that vision and I, and all of the team, will be reinforcing relationships, working collectively with our partners to protect and promote shared interests.

We are so very grateful for the support of our IPE partner nations, and look forward to strengthening our defence ties, forging new friendships, and deepening relationships.

Hope to see you all in this big, beautiful region we call home.

title: China's new materials industry gains momentum on green, AI technologies
description:
It showcased a range of cutting-edge materials and highlighted the remarkable growth of China's new materials industry.
China's booming electric vehicle industry, meanwhile, has spurred the growth of its new materials sector.
The application of cutting-edge technologies, such as AI, computing and genetic engineering, is also driving the growth of the new materials industry.
New materials leaders are also forging partnerships around the world for green growth.
It has been actively engaged in international cooperation and exchanges, promoting new materials, new technologies and high-quality services globally.
text:
HEFEI - From conference credentials to mineral water bottles and shopping bags, such everyday items at the 5th International New Materials Industry Conference held recently in Bengbu, East China's Anhui province, were made from an innovative material -- polylactic acid (PLA).

PLA, a biodegradable polymer derived from renewable biomass materials like corn and straw, is becoming a green and sustainable alternative to traditional plastics.

"PLA is a low-carbon and environmentally friendly material that holds the potential to replace traditional plastics and reduce dependence on fossil fuels," said Chen Liping, executive general manager of BBCA Group.

ALSO READ: Green fashion turns old plastics into profits

Widely used in packaging, textiles, medical applications and many other fields -- this material is helping to shape a more sustainable future. PLA-based biodegradable tableware was used both at the Beijing 2022 Winter Olympics and Winter Paralympics, Chen revealed.

Themed "New Technology, New Materials, New Future," the four-day conference attracted about 400 delegates from home and abroad. It showcased a range of cutting-edge materials and highlighted the remarkable growth of China's new materials industry.

A report released at the conference by CCID Consulting, under China's Ministry of Industry and Information Technology, showed that China's new materials industry had reached a scale of 8.7 trillion yuan ($1.2 trillion) in 2024, a year-on-year increase of 13.8 percent. Notably, the frontier materials sector surged 26.6 percent year on year to 329.2 billion yuan -- and is expected to exceed 500 billion yuan in 2026.

"As China advances new industrialization during the 15th Five-Year Plan period (2026-2030), the new materials industry is set to enter a golden period of growth," said Li Ke, vice president of CCID Consulting.

China's booming electric vehicle industry, meanwhile, has spurred the growth of its new materials sector.

Anhui Estone Materials Technology Co., Ltd., a national high-tech enterprise specializing in lithium battery safety materials, is making a significant impact with its self-developed boehmite material, which improves lithium battery safety.

The company holds nearly half of the global market share of this key new material, with clients from home and abroad, including leading vehicle battery giant CATL.

"When coated on lithium battery separators, boehmite forms a protective layer that significantly enhances heat resistance and thus battery safety," said Jiang Xuexin, chairman of Anhui Estone.

What's more, its ceramic flame retardant can form a high-strength ceramic layer at high temperatures -- acting like "diamond armor" for battery packs, which helps prevent thermal runaway in batteries, Jiang added.

READ MORE: Straws going green amid ecological concern

The integration of AI with new materials is unlocking new possibilities for the future. At Anhui North Microelectronics Research Institute Group Co., Ltd., a brain-computer interface (BCI) collector enables a crawler vehicle to flexibly perform movements such as driving forward, reversing and turning -- all via brain signals without the need for physical or voice commands.

"Our R&D teams have achieved technological breakthroughs in frontier materials such as non-invasive gel electrodes and brain signal acquisition chips," said Sun Beibei, head of the company's science and technology department.

"By integrating cutting-edge technologies such as AI, we are promoting the application of BCI products in industrial manufacturing, healthcare and other fields," Sun explained.

The application of cutting-edge technologies, such as AI, computing and genetic engineering, is also driving the growth of the new materials industry.

"The deep integration of AI, high-throughput computing and material genetic engineering will greatly accelerate the R&D efficiency of new materials and create new market opportunities," said Gan Yong, an academician of the Chinese Academy of Engineering.

New materials leaders are also forging partnerships around the world for green growth.

Last year, BBCA Group signed a strategic cooperation agreement with Honeywell to develop sustainable aviation fuel and other initiatives, aiming to support green and low-carbon development.

The company has also built production bases in Brazil, Hungary and Thailand, converting abundant local raw materials such as cassava, corn and soybeans into organic acids, starch sugars and PLA products.

As a leading enterprise in the new materials sector, China National Building Material Group accounts for over 65 percent of the international high-end glass engineering market. It has been actively engaged in international cooperation and exchanges, promoting new materials, new technologies and high-quality services globally.

"In the global new materials landscape, China is playing an increasingly significant role," said Erik Muijsenberg, vice president of the International Commission on Glass, adding that the development of the new materials industry requires collaborative innovation across industry, academia and research institutions as well as open cooperation from all sectors around the globe.

title: Building markets for Iowa ag products, both domestically and abroad, remains one of my top ...
description:
Building markets for Iowa ag products, both domestically and abroad, remains one of my top priorities, especially in a challenging ag economy.
One of the best ways we can strengthen demand for Iowa corn and soybeans is by continuing to grow our biofuels sector, including new and emerging opportunities.
That’s why I’m looking forward to moderating an upcoming webinar, “Insights to Innovation: Ethanol to Sustainable Aviation Fuel,” hosted by America's Cultivation Corridor on December 4 at 2:00 PM CST.
We've assembled an impressive panel of experts who will talk about how our long-standing leadership in biofuels is opening new doors -- from transforming ethanol into sustainable aviation fuel, to developing diverse feedstocks, to ensuring that Iowa remains at the center of global renewable fuel innovation.
Panelists include: Paul Nees, Head of Supply and Trading, Chevron Kendall Palmer, Senior Director of Biofuels, Corteva Agriscience Ryan Sauer, Vice President of Market Development, Iowa Corn Lisa Schulte Moore, Charles F. Curtiss Distinguished Professor and Co-Director of the Bioeconomy Institute, Iowa State University

title: Commentary on Sustainable Aviation Fuel Levy on Singapore's Air Cargo Sector – NUS SGFIN
description:
Associate Professor Zhang Weina, Deputy Director of SGFIN commented that the sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) levy on outbound cargo will likely be passed on to end customers.
This may negatively impact the price competitiveness of Singapore’s exports.
However, as transit and inbound cargo will be exempt from this levy, the impact on companies using Singapore as a transit logistics hub will be minimal.
She added that the efficiency and reliability of the Singapore’s airports far outweigh the cost of the levy.
The SAF levy is necessary and crucial to building a low-carbon aviation ecosystem in the long term.

title: Unlocking the Future of Sustainable Aviation Repost Council of Palm Oil Producing Countries
description:
Unlocking the Future of Sustainable Aviation 

Repost Council of Palm Oil Producing Countries : At the Argus Biofuels Europe Conference & Exhibition in London, CPOPC’s Secretary General Mdm. Izzana Salleh shared how palm-based residues and waste can be game-changers for scaling up Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF).

She emphasized that trust and transparency, through certification, traceability, and digital monitoring, are key to global recognition of palm-derived feedstocks.

From POME to EFB to PFAD, palm by-products hold tremendous potential to fuel the skies while advancing a circular, inclusive, and low-carbon economy. Supported by national certification schemes like MSPO and ISPO, these innovations show that palm oil can drive a sustainable energy transition, responsibly and transparently.
